p: Among the different pretreatments applied in this study, the simplest was reflux extraction (HD-RE). The incubation of finely milled plant material for 1 h at 40 °C in MiliQ water before hydrodistillation resulted in up to 60% essential oil yield increase. It was previously shown that such soaking of the plant material in water [ 40] or acidic medium [ 1] before distillation may increase the quantity of oil by enhancing the leaching of ingredients from the already disrupted cells. Also, swelling and hydration of plant material, which enlarge the pores in cell walls and increase the turgor pressure in the still intact plant cells, might lead to the enhanced diffusion of the oil ingredients into the soaking medium. For example, soaking of agarwood in lactic acid for 168 h [ 41] and soaking of thyme leaves in distilled water overnight at 50 °C improved the essential oil yield [ 40]. Thus, soaking of plant material before hydrodistillation, as applied here for selected Mediterranean plants, presents a simple and cost-effective treatment that results in a significant increase in essential oil yield.
